newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: JavaSoft to open offices in Asia.
newsitem.headline: JavaSoft to open offices in Asia.

text.p: Sun Microsystems Inc's JavaSoft will open several offices in Asia this year, JavaSoft president Alan Baratz said on Wednesday.
"JavaSoft has opened an office in Tokyo and we will be staffing throughout other countries over the course of the coming year," Baratz told a news conference.

He said the Tokyo set-up was an engineering organisation that handled localisation of Java, a computer language which enables programmers to write one piece of software that can run on many different systems.
Baratz declined to say how many offices would be set up in Asia or specify their locations.
The offices would undertake a combination of engineering, marketing and support functions and would have a total of about 20 staff, he said.
Officials from JavaSoft and its partners, including International Business Machines (IBM), Netscape Communications Corp and Novell Inc, were in Singapore for the Java Education World Tour.
The companies said they were promoting Java aggressively.
IBM would be opening a Java centre in Bangalore, India in June and one in Shanghai, China around July, said Cynthia Erdman, IBM's director of Asia Pacific, Solution Developer Marketing.
In Asia Pacific, IBM had opened one such centre in Sydney, Australia in March, where developers could go there to get their Java applications tested and validated.
